GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 94.001 TITLE; PURPOSE.
   (A)   This chapter shall be known as the City of Beech Grove Fire Prevention
and Protection Code.
   (B)   The purpose of this chapter is to prescribe regulations consistent
with nationally recognized standards for the protection of life, environment,
and property from the hazards of fire and explosion, from the hazards arising
from the storage, handling and use of hazardous materials, from conditions
hazardous to life or property in the use or occupancy of new or existing
buildings and premises, and to establish appropriate administrative procedures
for the enforcement of this chapter.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.002 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   "CLASS 1 STRUCTURE." Buildings and structures as defined in the Indiana
Administrative Code 675 IAC 12-6.
   "CLASS 2 STRUCTURE." Buildings and structures as defined in the Indiana
Administrative Code 675 IAC 12-6.
   "FIRE DEPARTMENT." The Beech Grove Fire Department that renders fire
prevention and protection services to the city.
   "INJURY PREVENTION BUREAU." The Fire Prevention Bureau established by this
chapter for the Beech Grove Fire Department located within the city.
   "INJURY PREVENTION CHIEF." The administrative head of the Fire Prevention
Bureau appointed pursuant to §
94.011.
   "HAZARDOUS CONDITION." The presence of a structural condition, equipment,
utility connection, materials which constitutes or poses a recognized threat of
fire or other injury to persons or property.
   "PRIVATE DWELLING." A building used exclusively as the personal residence of
one or two families.
   "MULTI-FAMILY DWELLING." A building containing three or more dwelling units
with independent cooking and bathroom facilities.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.003 APPLICABILITY.
   (A)   The provisions of this chapter shall be supplemental to the Indiana
Fire Code, as adopted by the Indiana Fire Prevention and Building Safety
Commission.
   (B)   The provisions of this chapter shall apply to maintenance of fire
prevention and life safety features as herein described.
   (C)   When any provision of this chapter is found to be in conflict with any
building, zoning, safety, health or other applicable law or ordinance of the
city existing on the effective date of this chapter, the provision which
established the higher standard for the promotion and protection of the safety
and welfare of the public shall prevail.
   (D)   The provisions of this chapter shall apply to existing conditions; as
well as to the conditions arising after the adoption thereof buildings,
systems, use processes, and equipment in existence on the effective date of
this approval shall be permitted to continue so long as they are maintained in
a condition that is equivalent to the quality and fire characteristics that
existed when the building was constructed, altered, added to or repaired.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.004 MINIMUM STANDARDS HEREBY ADOPTED BY REFERENCE.
   (A)   All fire safety rules of the Indiana Fire Prevention and Building
Safety Commission as set out in Article 22 of Title 675 of the Indiana
Administrative Code applicable to the city are hereby incorporated in this
chapter, and shall include later amendments to that article as the same
published in the Indiana Register or the Indiana Administrative Code with
effective dates as fixed therein.
   (B)   Any special processes or procedures not addressed in 675 IAC 22 shall
be subject to applications found in fire safety standards recognized by 675 IAC
22-2.2 or subsequent equivalent sections contained in fire safety rules adopted
by the Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission, and the Fire Chief.
   (C)   Any special processes or procedures in 675 IAC 22 shall be subject to
applications found in the current editions of the National Fire Protection
Association standards or other recognized fire safety standards, subject to the
rules of the Indiana Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission.
   (D)   A current copy of these standards shall be available in the Injury
Prevention Bureau office for inquiry and review by the public during normal
business hours.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
ORGANIZATION
§ 94.010 FIRE PREVENTION BUREAU ESTABLISHED; JURISDICTION.
   (A)   As authorized by IC 36-8-17 there is hereby established a local Fire
Prevention Bureau with in the Beech Grove Fire Department.
   (B)   The jurisdiction of the Fire Prevention Bureau shall be as follows.
The Fire Prevention Bureau established within the Beech Grove Fire Department
shall have jurisdiction within the city.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.011 ORGANIZATION OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT'S FIRE PREVENTION BUREAU.
   (A)   The Fire Prevention Bureau of the Beech Grove Fire Department shall be
under the supervision of the Injury Prevention Chief appointed pursuant to the
applicable personnel rules of the Beech Grove Fire Department. The jurisdiction
of the Fire Prevention Bureau shall be within the city.
   (B)   The local Fire Prevention Bureau established pursuant to §
94.010 shall be operated under the executive control of the Fire Chief and the
administrative supervision of the Injury Prevention Chief.
   (C)   The Injury Prevention Bureau of the Fire Department shall be under the
supervision of the Injury Prevention Chief appointed pursuant to the applicable
personnel rules of the Fire Department. The jurisdiction of the Fire Prevention
Bureau shall be within the city.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
INSPECTIONS AND INVESTIGATIONS
§ 94.020 RIGHT TO ENTER BUILDINGS AND PREMISES.
   (A)   Pursuant to IC 36-8-17, authorized personnel of the Beech Grove Fire
Department may, at all reasonable hours enter any structure (except the
interiors of private dwellings) within the city for the purposes of conducting
inspections. The right to enter hall extend to new structures under
construction as well as to existing, renovated or remodeled structures. The
Beech Grove Fire Department and its authorized personnel shall have the right
to enter common areas of multi-family dwellings.
   (B)   An inspector, investigator, or any employee of the Beech Grove Fire
Department may be required by the owner or occupant of such property to produce
satisfactory proof of his authority or identity.
   (C)   If an inspector, investigator, or any employee of the Beech Grove Fire
Department is denied access, the Injury Prevention Chief, under the direction
of the Fire Chief may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for an order
allowing inspection or investigation.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.021 FIRE INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   The Beech Grove Fire Department shall perform inspections under the
administrative supervision of the Injury Prevention Chief pursuant to IC 36-8-
17.
   (B)   The Beech Grove Fire Department may, as often as may be reasonably
necessary.
      (1)   Inspect every place and public area, except the interiors of
private dwellings;
      (2)   Inspect upon receipt of a complaint, any building or premises, and
public areas except interiors of private dwellings; and
      (3)   Inspect upon receipt of a complaint any common area of a multi-
family dwelling.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.022 FIRE INVESTIGATIONS.
   (A)   The Beech Grove Fire Department shall perform fire investigations
under the administrative supervision of the Injury Prevention Chief pursuant to
IC 36-8-17-7.
   (B)   The Beech Grove Fire Department shall investigate, assist in the
prosecution of, and support suppression of arson and other crimes associated
with the destruction or attempted destruction of property by fire in the city,
shall take immediate charge of the physical evidence, notify any other
authorities designated by law to assist in the investigation of such matters,
and cooperate with such other authorities in the prosecution of the case.
Reports prepared pursuant to this section shall be in the form prescribed by
the Injury Prevention Chief of the division and shall contain a statement of
all facts relating to the cause, origin and circumstances of the fire, the
extent of damage, the approximate loss, and any other appropriate information
concerning the fire.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.023 RECORDS, REPORTS AND REPRODUCTION FEES.
   (A)   The Beech Grove Fire Department shall keep a record of all fires and
the facts concerning their, including statistics as to the extent of fires and
the losses sustained. Such reports shall be prepared into a monthly report and
an annual report submitted to the Board of Public Works and Safety. The annual
report, together with recommendations, shall be submitted, by the 31st day of
January of the following year. The Beech Grove Fire Department shall maintain
files containing reports of all properties that have been inspected, all orders
issued, of all complaints and fires investigated, and the location of all
buildings containing hazardous occupancies. Such files shall be under the
direct control of the Injury Prevention Chief.
   (B)   A reproduction fee of $2 shall be charged for a paper report. A $15
fee shall be charged for the reproduction of a VHS tape and or a cassette tape.
A $5 fee shall be charged for each individual still picture taken.
   (C)   No charge shall be assessed for the reproduction of a paper report,
VHS tape, cassette tape and or a individual still picture to any city, county,
state and or federal government agency.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
ENFORCEMENT RESPONSIBILITY
§ 94.030 ENFORCEMENT.
   It shall be the responsibility of the Beech Grove Fire Department to enforce
all provisions of this chapter within its jurisdiction.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.031 LEGAL ASSISTANCE.
   The Beech Grove Fire Department shall obtain the services of the City
Attorney for legal assistance in connection with the enforcement of this
chapter.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.032 CONCURRENT JURISDICTION WITH THE DEPARTMENT OF METROPOLITAN
DEVELOPMENT, STATE FIRE MARSHAL'S OFFICE AND THE MARION COUNTY BOARD OF HEALTH.
   The Department of Metropolitan Development, State Fire Marshal's Office and
The Marion County Board of Health have concurrent jurisdiction with the Beech
Grove Fire Department for the enforcement of any other violation of this
chapter in which;
   (A)   The Beech Grove Fire Department has actual knowledge of such a
violation; and
   (B)   Such violation creates an immediate fire hazard, which endangers life,
property or the public safety.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.033 COORDINATED ENFORCEMENT.
   Whenever it shall be the responsibility of more that one official or
governmental agency to enforce the provisions of this chapter, it shall be the
duty of the enforcement officials to coordinate their inspections and
administrative orders so far as is possible, so that the owners and occupants
of the building shall not be subjected to unnecessary inspections, nor to
multiple or conflicting orders.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURES
§ 94.040 NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS.
   Under IC 36-8-17-9, the enforcement of 675 IAC 22, this chapter, or any
other provision of this code which is within the jurisdiction of the City of
Beech Grove, the Beech Grove Fire Department's Fire Prevention Bureau may seek
the correction of any violation or the elimination of any hazardous condition,
by the methods specified in this division or by any other appropriate remedy or
procedure provided by law.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.041 DETERMINATION OF VIOLATION.
   Whenever a duly authorized inspector or investigator for the Beech Grove
Fire Department's Fire Prevention Bureau determines by inspection that a
violation of this chapter or a hazardous condition exists upon any premise
within the bureau's jurisdiction, the person making such determination shall
issue such orders as may be necessary for the protection of the environment and
persons and property from fire and explosion.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-2003)
§ 94.042 CONVEYANCE OF INSPECTION REPORT.
   A copy of the inspection report with violations and safety recommendations
shall be served upon the owner, operator, occupant or person responsible for
the building property. Service of such report shall be by personal service, or
by affixing a copy thereof in a conspicuous place at the entrance of said
building or premises and or by mailing a copy thereof to the owner or occupant
by certified mail to the owner's or occupant's last known address pursuant to
IC4-21.5-3. Such report shall include a right to appeal form. The owners and or
occupant shall be provided with information of their right to appeal any fire
code violation noted during the course of an inspection.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.043 IMMINENT DANGER.
   The Injury Prevention. Chief under the direction of the Fire Chief may order
the operation or use stopped, or the evacuation, of any premises, building or
vehicle or portion thereof under IC 36-8-17-9 when it is determined that
conduct or conditions of the property;
   (A)   Present a clear and immediate hazard of death or serious bodily injury
to any person other than a trespasser;
   (B)   Are prohibited without a permit, registration, certification, release,
authorization, variance, exemption or other license required under IC 22-14 or
another statute administered by the State of Indiana Department of Fire and
Building Services and the license has not been issued; or
   (C)   Will conceal a violation of law.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.044 DUTY TO CORRECT VIOLATIONS.
   In the event of imminent danger as defined in §
94.043 above, the owner or person in control of any premises or building upon
which a violation or hazard exists shall do one or more of the following, at
the order of the Fire Chief;
   (A)   Cease and correct the violation;
   (B)   Protect persons and property from the hazards of the violation and
correct the violation; or
   (C)   Require persons to leave the area that is affected by a violation and
prohibit persons from entering the area until the violation is corrected.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.045 VARIANCES, VARIANCE APPLICATION, AND APPLICATION FEES.
   (A)   An owner or occupant requesting a variance from the state adopted fire
and building laws as set forth by IC 22-13-2-11 shall apply for such from the
Indiana Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission in accordance with 675
IAC 12-5.
   (B)   An owner or occupant requesting a variance from the provisions of this
chapter that are not part of the state adopted fire and building laws as set
forth by IC22-13-2-11 shall apply in writing to the Fire Chief. The granting of
a variance shall be considered only upon the written application of the owner
of the property, stating that:
      (1)   Practical difficulties have been encountered in the implementation
of specific requirements of this chapter;
      (2)   Compliance with specific requirements of this chapter will cause
unnecessary hardship to the owner; and
      (3)   The owner desires to take advantage of new methods or equipment
which are recognized as adequate for the purpose for which they are to be
substituted.
   (C)   An owner or occupant requesting a variance from this chapter shall be
required to pay a fee of $138 to apply for such a variance request. Payment of
the variance application fee does not guarantee that the variance will be
approved by the Fire Chief after review. Fees for the application of a variance
shall be made payable to the city.
   (D)   A variance may be granted only if the Fire Chief determines in writing
that; (1) the requested use or modification will conform with fundamental
requirements for safety; and (2) the granting of the variance does not increase
the risk of fire or danger to the public. A copy of any variance decision shall
be retained in the respective file under the direction of the Injury Prevention
Chief.
   (E)   A variance shall be enforced in the same manner as an order issued
under §
94.040 with the variance of this chapter.
   (F)   Should the Fire Chief deny a variance request from this chapter, the
owner or occupant filing the variance request shall have the right to appeal
the decision of the Fire Chief to the Board of Public Works and Safety. Such
appeal shall be initiated within 18 business days of the Fire Chief's decision.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.046 ORDERS TO CORRECT VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   The Fire Chief or his or her authorized representative is empowered to
issue an order forbidding the occupancy of any structure or part of any
structure, in accordance with IC 36-8-17-9.
   (B)   The failure of the Beech Grove Fire Department's Fire Prevention
Bureau to inspect or to issue an order in accordance with this chapter shall
not constitute approval of any violation or noncompliance with the provisions
of this chapter.
   (C)   Any order issued pursuant to this section shall be served upon the
owner, operator, occupant or other person responsible for the building
property. Service of such order shall be by personal service, or by affixing a
copy thereof in a conspicuous place at the entrance of said building or
premises and or by mailing a copy thereof to the owner or occupant by certified
mail to the owner's or occupant's last known address pursuant to IC 4-21.5-3.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.047 ORDER FORBIDDING OCCUPANCY.
   (A)   The Fire Chief or his or her authorized representative is empowered to
issue an order forbidding the occupancy of any structure or part of any
structure, in accordance with IC 36-8-17-9.
   (B)   The Fire Chief or his or her authorized representative, is empowered
to issue an order forbidding continued construction of a building or structure
when the building, structure or property under construction is in violation of
state or local fire prevention codes and continuation will:
      (1)   Conceal a violation of law;
      (2)   Be inaccessible to the Beech Grove Fire Department's apparatus; or
      (3)   Provide insufficient water supply to adequately suppress a fire as
required by this chapter.
   (C)   The order forbidding occupancy or continued construction shall be in
writing, specifying whether it is applicable to the entire structure, part of
structure, or the property under development. The order shall state the reason
for issuance and the conditions under which the structure, part of the
structure or property may be occupied or construction continued. The order
shall be posted on the structure in a conspicuous location and if conveniently
possible, shall be given to the owner of the property or his agent and to any
other responsible person supervising work on the premises.
   (D)   Should an order be issued by the Fire Chief forbidding occupancy, the
owner or occupant has the right to appeal such order as set forth in §
94.042 of this subchapter.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.048 APPEAL FROM ORDERS.
   An owner or occupant who remains aggrieved by the decision issued pursuant
to this chapter and the matter involves a rule of the Indiana Fire Prevention
and Building Safety Commission, may appeal to such Commission as set forth by
IC 36-8-17.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.049 REMEDIES.
   Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter or who shall fail
to comply with any order issued under this chapter, or who shall fail to comply
with or to obtain any permit required hereunder, could be subject to fines not
exceeding $100 (one hundred dollars) a day. After each ten days a violation
continues, it shall constitute an additional violation, provided however that
the penalty for any violation shall not exceed $2,500.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
EMERGENCY OPERATIONS
EMERGENCY SERVICES
§ 94.060 AUTHORITY AT FIRES AND EMERGENCIES.
   The Fire Chief, or his or her designated representative, at any fire,
explosion, or other emergency which poses imminent threat to life, environment,
or property, shall have the authority to direct operations as may be necessary
to control, extinguish, perform special operations, and investigate the
existence of hazardous conditions in connection with such fire, explosion, any
other emergency, or to take other action reasonably necessary to contain,
mitigate, or eliminate the emergency.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.061 EMERGENCY LINES AND LIMITS.
   (A)   The Fire Chief, or his or her designated representative or any law
enforcement officer may establish emergency lines and limits and barricade or
guard from the general public such emergency lines and limits. The Fire Chief,
or his designated representative, or law enforcement officer may create an area
in which only firefighters, law enforcement officers and those having a direct
interest in any property threatened by the fire, explosion, or other emergency,
or other people or agencies at the discretion of the Beech Grove Fire
Department or the Beech Grove Police Department shall be admitted.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to cross such
emergency lines or limits.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
Penalty, see § 94.999
§ 94.062 UNLAWFUL INTERFERENCE WITH FIRE PROTECTION EQUIPMENT, BARRIERS,
DEVICES, SIGNS, AND SEALS.
   It shall be unlawful for a person to do or permit to be done any of the
following
acts:
   (A)   "KEY BOX ACCESS AND FIRE EQUIPMENT KEYS." To make or cause or permit
to be made or have in his or her possession any key for any key box emergency
access system, fire department equipment, house or building used by the Beech
Grove Fire Department, except upon the written order of the Fire Chief, or to
fail or refuse to surrender possession of any such key upon demand of the Fire
Chief.
   (B)   "TAMPERING WITH FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEM." To tamper, molest, destroy or
remove or in any manner interfere with, damage, or disturb any part of the fire
protection system, apparatus, equipment or devices in use in the city.
   (C)   "INJURING FIRE HOSE." To drive any motor vehicle or railroad
locomotive over any fire hose laid in any street in the vicinity of any fire or
while in use for any other purpose, or in any other way interfere with the use
of such hose.
   (D)   "OPENING OF HYDRANTS." To use or operate any public or private
hydrants or valves connected to a water system intended for fire suppression
purposes without written permission from the Indianapolis Water Company or the
Beech Grove Fire Department. Notwithstanding the provisions of this subsection,
employees of the Indianapolis Water Company who are authorized, members of the
Beech Grove Fire Department, owners of private fire hydrants, and members of a
duly recognized facility fire brigade may operate hydrants and valves as part
of their assigned duties.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
Penalty, see § 94.999
§ 94.063 INTERFERENCE PENALTY.
   Person or persons found to unlawfully access key boxes or pertinent keys,
tamper with fire protection systems, injure or destroy fire hose, or unlawfully
open hydrants shall be reported to the local law enforcement agency for
documentation. It shall be at the discretion of local law enforcement to file a
report or incident to the Marion County Prosecutors Office for review by the
Felony Screening Division for accuracy and filing purposes.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
GENERAL REQUIREMENTS FOR SAFETY OF BUILDINGS
FIRE PROTECTION EQUIPMENT
§ 94.070 PLANS FOR FIRE PROTECTION SYSTEMS.
   In the event a set of plans and specifications for fire protection systems,
including fire alarm systems, automatic sprinkler systems, standpipe systems,
and other special types of fire extinguishing or detecting systems and
appurtenances thereto is created, then such documents shall be submitted to the
Beech Grove Fire Department for review and information purposes.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.071 PORTABLE FIRE EXTINGUISHERS; WHERE REQUIRED.
   (A)   Except for private dwellings, portable fire extinguishers shall be
installed and maintained in all Class 1 (as defined in IC 22-12-1-4) structures
of more than 500 square feet and designed for occupancy built and placed in
service after January 1, 2002, as set forth in N.F.P.A. Standard No. 10,
currently adopted by the Indiana Fire Prevention and Building Safety
Commission.
   (B)   Notwithstanding other provisions of this chapter, portable fire
extinguisher equipment required for Class 1 multi-family apartment buildings
shall be as follows:
      (1)   A minimum 2-A, 10BC rated dry chemical extinguisher shall be placed
at intervals of 75 feet travel distance on each floor level in all common areas
of all apartments. The requirements of this paragraph are satisfied if each
individual apartment shall have a minimum 1-A, 10BC rated dry chemical
extinguisher installed in the unit; and
      (2)   Each laundry room and storage area shall have a minimum 2-A, 10BC
rated dry chemical extinguisher. Each clubhouse and maintenance building or
room shall have a minimum 2-A, 10BC rated dry extinguisher placed at intervals
of 75 feet travel distance. Notwithstanding the provisions of this subsection,
laundry rooms and storage areas contiguous to the common corridors which have
proper extinguishers placed at intervals of 75 feet travel distance are exempt
from this division.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.072 SERVICING OF PORTABLE FIRE EXTINGUISHERS.
   Portable fire extinguishers which are required by §
94.071 shall be serviced and maintained per the latest edition of N.F.P.A.
Standard No. 10 as adopted in 675 IAC 22.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.073 REQUIREMENTS FOR COMMERCIAL KITCHEN EXHAUST EQUIPMENT AND FIRE
PROTECTION EQUIPMENT.
   Any new installation of commercial kitchen fire suppression equipment within
the city shall be inspected by the Fire Prevention Bureau prior to the kitchen
cooking equipment being placed in-service. The installing company shall:
   (A)   Use installers that are certified by the manufacturer;
   (B)   Notify the Fire Prevention Bureau at least 24 hours in advance of the
system being completed for system testing; and
   (C)   File with the Fire Prevention Bureau a form stating that the system
has been inspected and is fully operational, signed by the installation
company's representative. This form is to be kept on file in the Injury
Prevention Office.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.074 REQUIRED WATER SUPPLY FOR FIRE PROTECTION.
   (A)   All Class 1 structures or portions of Class 1 structures hereafter
constructed shall be provided with a water supply capable of providing the
required fire flow, for fire-fighting purposes for a minimum period of two
hours. The water supply shall be from a source as set forth in section 903.2 of
675 IAC 22-2.2.
   (B)   In setting the requirements for fire flow, the Beech Grove Fire
Department shall use 675 IAC 22-2.2, Appendix III-A as a guide. Notwithstanding
the provisions of this subsection, a reduction in required fire flow of 75% is
allowed when the building is providing with an approved automatic sprinkler
system. The resulting fire flow shall not be less than 1,000 gpm at 20 psi
residual.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.075 FIRE HYDRANTS.
   (A)   All private hydrants and water mains shall be installed and maintained
as set forth in the 1995 edition of N.F.P.A. Standard No. 24. The Injury
Prevention Chief in determining location and spacing of hydrants shall use 675
IAC 222.2 Appendix III-B as a guide.
   (B)   The proposed location of private hydrants to supply the required fire
flow shall be approved by the Beech Grove Fire Department prior to construction
of any Class 1 buildings. Whenever the provisions of this chapter require the
installation of a fire hydrant, whether on public or private property, such
hydrant shall meet the following specifications:
      (1)   It shall be equipped with a five and one-quarter-inch main valve
opening;
      (2)   It shall be constructed with two 2 1/2-inch hose nozzles with six
"V" threads per inch;
      (3)   It shall be equipped with one 4 1/2-inch streamer nozzle with six
"V" threads per inch;
      (4)   It shall be constructed to be opened by turning clockwise a
national standard pentagon operating nut;
      (5)   The source of water supply shall be buried a minimum of five feet
below the ground level at the hydrant; and
      (6)   The hydrant shall be constructed with a break-off feature to
prevent the hydrant from leaking when damaged by collision.
   (D)   Nonfunctional hydrants shall not be located within 20 feet of any
waterline easement, and shall be secured to prevent attempted usage.
   (E)   All privately owned fire hydrants shall be painted red or yellow.
   (F)   Only approved hydrant wrenches shall be used to open or close a fire
hydrant.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.076 MARKING OF FIRE PROTECTION EQUIPMENT, FIRE HYDRANTS AND ACCESS ROADS.
   (A)   Fire-protection equipment and fire hydrants whether public or private
shall be clearly identified in a manner approved by the Beech Grove Fire
Department to prevent obstruction by parking and other obstructions.
   (B)   Fire access roads shall be identified as fire lanes and the provisions
set forth in §
94.121 shall apply.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.077 SMOKE AND HEAT REMOVAL EQUIPMENT.
   (A)   When smoke and heat removal equipment are required in buildings
hereafter constructed, they shall be installed as set forth in the 675 IAC 22
and 675 IAC 13.
   (B)   Prior to the installation of any engineered mechanical smoke removal
system, the fire control panel shall be of a design and at a location approved
by the Beech Grove Fire Department.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.078 FIRE PROTECTION IN RECREATIONAL VEHICLE, MOBILE HOMES AND MANUFACTURED
HOUSING PARKS, SALE AND STORAGE LOTS.
   Recreational vehicle, mobile home and manufactured housing parks, sales lots
and storage lots, hereafter constructed or added to, shall provide and maintain
fire hydrants and access roads in accordance with 675 IAC 22-2.2, sections 902
and 903.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
SMOKE DETECTORS
§ 94.090 DWELLINGS; SMOKE DETECTOR REQUIREMENTS.
   (A)   A smoke detector shall be defined for the purposes of this section as
a device, which detects visible or invisible products of combustion.
   (B)   Each smoke detector shall detect abnormal quantities of smoke that can
occur in a dwelling, shall properly operate in the normal environmental
conditions of a household, and shall be in compliance with ANSI/UL 268-standard
for safety smoke detectors for fire protective signaling systems, or ANSI/UL
217-standard for safety single and multiple station smoke detectors.
   (C)   All private dwelling units within the city shall be equipped with a
minimum of one functional, properly located, labeled and listed smoke detector
as described in N.F.P.A. Standard No. 72 latest edition. Smoke detectors shall
be installed outside of each separate sleeping area in the immediate vicinity
of the bedrooms and on each additional story of the family living unit,
including basements and excluding crawl spaces and unfinished attics. In family
living units with one or more split-levels where there is an intervening door
between one level and the adjacent lower level, a smoke detector shall also be
installed on the lower level. In new construction beginning on or after the
effective date of this chapter a smoke detector also shall be installed in each
sleeping room. Where more than one smoke detector is required; detectors shall
be arranged so that operation of any smoke detector causes the alarm in all
smoke detectors within the dwelling to sound.
   (D)   All equipment shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's
installation requirements and recommendations. If the method of installation is
not specified by the manufacturer, the smoke detector shall be installed on the
ceiling at least four inches from the wall or on a wall with the top of the
detector not less that four inches nor more than 12 inches below the ceiling.
Smoke detectors in rooms with ceiling slopes greater than one foot in eight
feet horizontally shall be located at the high side of the room.
   (E)   Smoke detectors required by 676 IAC 13 or 675 IAC 14 (multi-family
dwellings) shall have the power supply as specified by the applicable code. All
other residential smoke detectors may be powered by an AC power source or a
battery. If the detector is solely AC powered and the manufacturer does not
supply installation specifications, it shall be directly attached to a junction
box with power supplied either from a dedicated branch circuit or the
unswitched portion of a branch circuit also used for power and lighting, and
such installation shall be in accordance with 675 IAC 17.
   (F)   It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with or remove any smoke
detector, except when it is necessary for maintenance or inspection purposes.
Any smoke detector removed for repair, replacement or local remodeling shall be
reinstalled or replaced so that it is in place and operable immediately upon
completion of such repair, replacement or local remodeling.
      (1)   Rental dwelling units. Each owner or manager or rental agent of the
owner and or tenant is responsible for the installation of required smoke
detectors and the repair or replacement of a required smoke detector within two
business days after the owner, manager, or rental agent is given written
notification of the need to repair or replace the smoke detector. Owners,
managers or rental agents shall inspect and test the smoke detectors in
accordance with the manufacturer's instructions at least monthly.
      (2)   Owner dwelling units. Each owner is responsible for the
installation of required smoke detectors and the repair or replacement of a
required smoke detector within two business days of finding it inoperable. An
owner shall inspect and test the smoke detectors for power in accordance with
manufacturer's instructions at least monthly.
   (G)   A person, company, or corporation violating IC 22-11-18-3, IC 22-11-
18-3.5 and provisions of this chapter shall be subject to penalties as
specified in IC 22-11-18-5. Each day such violation is permitted to continue
may be deemed to constitute a separate offense, provided however, the aggregate
penalty for any violation shall not exceed $2,500.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
SMOKE DETECTOR COMPLIANCE FOR RESIDENTIAL SALES
§ 94.100 SMOKE DETECTOR COMPLIANCE FOR CLOSING PURPOSES.
   (A)   No residential property shall be sold or traded in the city unless and
until the seller installs smoke detectors in accordance with §
94.090.
   (B)   Such inspections shall be ordered by the property owner or their
representative and be scheduled with the Beech Grove Fire Department.
   (C)   Upon inspection the Beech Grove Fire Department shall inspect each
dwelling unit and each required smoke detector for proper placement and
operation prior to issuance of the certification paperwork.
   (D)   Should the dwelling unit not have smoke detectors properly located
within or such smoke detectors are found not to be installed or not working
properly, the certification paperwork shall not be issued.
   (E)   Any and all paperwork including certification slips shall be kept on
file by the Injury Prevention Chief.
   (F)   There shall be no fee charged to provide this service.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)   
Penalty, see § 94.999
MEANS OF EGRESS
§ 94.110 MEANS OF EGRESS ILLUMINATION AND SIGNS.
   (A)   Means of egress illumination shall be provided and maintained in
accordance with the rules of the Fire Prevention and Safety Commission in
effect at the time of construction. Means of egress shall be illuminated and
exit signs shall be maintained when the building or structure is occupied.
   (B)   Any replacement of exit signs in existing buildings or structures or
installation of additional exit signs shall meet the requirements of the rules
of the Fire Prevention and Building Commission.
   (C)   Equipment providing emergency power for means of egress illumination
and exit signs shall be maintained in an operable condition.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.111 EXIT DOOR, STAIRWAY AND ELEVATOR SIGNS.
   (A)   Exit doors shall be readily distinguishable from adjacent construction
and shall be easily recognizable as an exit door. Exit doors shall be as set
forth in the rules of the Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission.
   (B)   Stairway identification signs shall be located at each floor level in
all buildings as set forth in the rules of the Fire Prevention and Building
Safety Commission.
   (C)   Instructions for operation of elevators under fire and other emergency
conditions shall be as set forth in the rules of the Fire Prevention and
Building Safety Commission.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.112 OBSTRUCTION OF THE MEANS OF EGRESS.
   (A)   Obstructions, including storage, shall not be placed in the required
width of a means of egress, except projections as allowed by the rules of the
Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission. Means of egress shall not be
obstructed in any manner and shall remain free of any material or matter where
its presence would obstruct or render the means of egress hazardous.
   (B)   Any member of the Beech Grove Police or Fire Department who shall
discover any fire escape or means of egress encumbered or obstructed in any
manner shall report such condition to the appropriate Injury Prevention Bureau
Officer and such Officer shall immediately notify the owner or occupant to
remove such encumbrance or obstacle.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)   
Penalty, see § 94.999
§ 94.113 INSPECTION OF FIRE ESCAPES.
   Exterior fire escapes shall comply with the requirements as set forth in the
rules of the Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission. Certification by a
professional engineer licensed in the State of Indiana to show compliance with
this section shall be filed with the Fire Prevention Bureau upon order of the
Injury Prevention Chief.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS
§ 94.120 SMOKING.
   (A)   As used in this chapter, smoke and smoking materials shall include the
carrying of a lighted pipe, cigar, cigarette or tobacco in any form.
   (B)   No person shall smoke or carry a lighted match or lighter in the
following places;
      (1)   Indoor Public Assembly Occupancies;
      (2)   Educational occupancies;
      (3)   Institutional occupancies;
      (4)   Retail selling establishments; and
      (5)   Buildings, except residential occupancies, which contain explosives
or combustibles materials, any of which would be thereby exposed to ignition;
   Which the Injury Prevention Chief designates as a "no smoking area" because
of the fire dangers which smoking could cause. Provided, however, the owner of
the above-enumerated places may designate rest rooms, smoking rooms or other
areas where smoking is permissible if such smoking room or area has been
approved by the Injury Prevention Chief.
   (C)   No person shall smoke in any elevator.
   (D)   The owner or occupant shall post approved "no smoking" signs in each
building, structure, room or place in which smoking is prohibited. Signs shall
be conspicuously and suitably located and shall be maintained. However, this
section does not apply to buildings or structures which are smoke-free
environments and are posted as such at all public and employee entrances, and
where no visible evidence of prohibited smoking exists within the building
structure.
   (E)   No person shall remove any legally required "NO SMOKING" sign or smoke
in any areas where such signs are posted.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)   
Penalty, see § 94.999
§ 94.121 UNDERGROUND STORAGE TANKS; NOTIFICATIONS.
   (A)   Any person who supervises, manages, or directs the installation,
retrofitting, removal or closure of underground storage tanks shall notify the
Beech Grove Fire Department 14 days prior to commencement of work; however,
this requirement shall not apply in emergency repair work where 14-day
notification is not possible.
   (B)   All applicable permits and notification shall be made to the State
Fire Marshal's Office and the Indiana Department of Environmental Management
prior to removing or closing underground storage tanks and all associated
piping.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
PERMITS AND CERTIFICATES OF INSURANCE
§ 94.130 FIREWORKS.
   (A)   No person, group or business shall conduct a public display of
fireworks without first obtaining a permit from the city. Any and all permits
for the public display of fireworks shall be obtained by the person, group or
business that is conducting the display. Such permit shall be approved by the
Board of Public Works and Safety.
   (B)   Fireworks and the temporary storage, use, handing of pyrotechnic
special effects material used in motion pictures, television, theatrical and
group entertainment productions shall be in accordance with IC 22-11-14 and the
applicable rules of the Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission
currently in effect.
   (C)   A certificate of insurance conditioned for the payment of all damages
which may be caused either to a person or persons in an amount of not less than
$1,000,000, holding the city harmless from liability shall be reason for the
licensed display, arising from any acts of the licensee, his or her agents,
employees or subcontractors. The certificate of insurance shall be presented to
the Clerk/ Treasurer for proper filing.
   (D)   The fee for each permit issued pursuant to each public display of
fireworks shall be $50 payable to the city.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
Penalty, see § 94.999
HALLOWEEN AMUSEMENTS
§ 94.140 HALLOWEEN AMUSEMENT DEFINED.
   As used in this division, Halloween amusement means haunted house, house of
horrors, or any other activity in which persons are invited, guided, escorted,
or otherwise transported through a building or structure or portion of a
building or structure, temporary or permanent, for the purpose of entertainment
or amusement.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.141 REQUIRED; PERMIT APPLICATION; PERMIT AND FEES.
   (A)   No person shall operate a Halloween amusement without first obtaining
a permit from the city. Such permit shall be approved by the Board of Public
Works and Safety.
   (B)   An application for a Halloween amusement permit shall be obtained from
the city and shall contain the following information.
      (1)   The name of the organization sponsoring the amusement;
      (2)   The name of the person(s) in charge of the amusement operations;
      (3)   The period of time (dates and hours) in, which the amusement will
be operated.
      (4)   The person or organization wishing to obtain a permit to operate a
Halloween amusement shall provide a certificate of insurance in the amount not
less than $1,000,000 holding the city harmless from any liability.
   (C)   The fee for each permit issued pursuant to this division shall be $250
payable to the city. The certificate of insurance shall be presented to the
Clerk/ Treasurer for proper filing.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
Penalty, see § 94.999
WHOLESALE AND RETAIL FIREWORK STANDS
§ 94.150 RETAIL FIREWORK STANDS OR BUSINESSES.
   (A)   An individual or company who desires to sell wholesale or retail
fireworks within the city shall obtain a permit from the State of Indiana prior
to the selling of merchandise to the general public.
   (B)   Upon the issuance of a permit through the State of Indiana, such
individual or company who desires to sell wholesale or retail fireworks within
the city, shall obtain a local permit from the city, prior to the selling of
fireworks to the general public.
   (C)   Such fee schedule per stand or business shall be as follows: A fee of
$276 shall be assessed for each temporary stand or business that opens.
   (D)   Fees for permits pursuant to wholesale or retail sale of fireworks
shall be made payable to the city.
   (E)   Permits issued by the city for the purpose of selling wholesale or
retail fireworks within the city shall expire 30 days after issuance of such
permit.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.151 AMUSEMENT INSPECTIONS.
   (A)   The authorized representative of the Fire Prevention Bureau shall
inspect the building or structure and the Halloween amusement as often as may
be reasonably necessary for compliance with applicable fire and life safety
requirements for its intended occupancy.
   (B)   Such inspections shall occur after the issuance of a permit, during
facility construction and during the permit period.
   (C)   Permits issued for Halloween amusements shall expire 30 days after
issuance of such permit.
   (D)   Violations found during any inspection conducted by the Beech Grove
Fire Department's Fire Prevention Bureau shall cause the amusement to shut down
in accordance with IC 36-8-17-9 and the revocation of the permit.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.152 PERMIT ISSUANCE AND TRANSFERABILITY.
   (A)   A Halloween amusement permit shall be issued only after the Beech
Grove Fire Department's Fire Prevention Bureau has had an opportunity to
inspect the subject premises, and has found that the building or structure and
amusement conforms with all applicable fire and life safety requirements as set
forth in the applicable rules of the Fire Prevention and Building Safety
Commission currently in effect and this Code.
   (B)   A permit issued pursuant to this division shall not be transferable,
and any change in use or occupancy of premises shall require a new permit.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.153 APPEAL FROM DENIAL OF PERMIT.
   When the Beech Grove Fire Department rejects or refuses to grant a permit
required by this chapter, or when it is claimed that provisions of this section
of this chapter relating thereto do not apply, the person may appeal the
decision in writing to the Board of Public Works and Safety.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.154 PERMIT PERIOD.
   Each permit granted under the provisions of this division shall be for such
period as indicated on the permit and permit application; however, such permit
shall expire 30 days from the date of the year in which it is issued.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.155 DISPLAY OF PERMIT REQUIRED.
   A permit issued pursuant to this division shall at all times be in a
conspicuous place on the premises designated in the permit and shall at all
times be subject to inspection by anyone duly authorized by the fire or police
department.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
Penalty, see § 94.999
OUTSIDE FIRE PROTECTION
§ 94.160 FIRE PROTECTION BY THE FIRE DEPARTMENT OUTSIDE THE CITY.
   The Beech Grove Fire Department may provide fire protection or services
outside the boundaries of the city, only under the following circumstances and
upon the following conditions:
   (A)   If the Board of Public Works and Safety enters into any mutual aid
agreement with any existing municipal fire department or with the chief
executive officer of any unit of government which maintains or finances an
established fire department, wherein the agreement provides for the mutual
assistance between the Beech Grove Fire Department and the other fire
department's such that the ranking officer of the respective departments' may
request, when necessary, the assistance without charge to the assisted
department. The Beech Grove Fire Department is authorized to render such
assistance as is requested by the ranking officer on duty with the respective
department so long as the rendering of such assistance shall not endanger the
citizens of the city or threaten the ability of the Beech Grove Fire Department
to render services within the city.
   (B)   The Board of Public Works and Safety, upon approval of the Mayor, may
enter into a contract with any person, business, municipality or other
governmental unit which is situated at a place not within the city, but within
the county and which is desirous of contracting with the city for regular fire
protection involving the use and services of the Beech Grove Fire Department.
The details of such contract shall be specified by the Board of Public Works
and Safety, but each contract must provide that the city furnish on a calendar
year basis such firefighting service and emergency services as may be
reasonably necessary on the request of the contracting person, municipality or
other governmental unit, but that obligation to render such services shall not
exist at any time that the same would endanger or threaten the services of the
Beech Grove Fire Department to the citizens of the city. The contract shall
also provide for a negotiated rate or fees payable as required by the Board of
Public Works and Safety for the rendering of such services and may provide for
additional charges based on the actual services and apparatus used in the
performance of such agreement.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
FIRE REPORTING SYSTEMS
§ 94.170 SCOPE OF DIVISION.
   This division shall cover installation and maintenance of all manual and
automatic fire alarm systems in new and existing buildings. Also, faulty and/or
false alarms and delayed notification of manual or automatic systems.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.171 MONITORING OF FIRE SYSTEMS.
   Fire alarm systems required by the applicable rules of the Fire Prevention
and Building Safety Commission or this chapter shall be monitored as set forth
in the applicable rules of the Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission
and the 1996 edition of N.F.P.A. Standard No. 72 or the most current edition of
the standard by an approved central proprietary or remote station service or a
local alarm which gives audible and visual signals as a constantly attended
location.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.172 NOTIFICATION UPON FIRE ALARM ACTIVATION AND EMERGENCY REPORTING.
   The Beech Grove Fire Department shall be notified upon the activation of any
fire alarm.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.173 FALSE ALARMS.
   (A)   Whenever the Beech Grove Fire Department responds to any fire alarm,
medical alarm, or emergency telephone call at a residence, business, premise or
building more that three times in a 30-day period due to improper alarm
installation, lack of maintenance, servicing, employee and or occupant failure,
or false reporting, a service charge shall be imposed.
   (B)   For a fourth response in a 30-day period, the service charge will be
$50. For a fifth response in a 30-day period, the service charge shall be $75.
For sixth and subsequent responses in a 30-day period the service charge shall
be $100 per each response.
   (c)   Such service charges shall be made payable to the city.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
CONCLUSION
§ 94.190 SEVERABILITY.
   (A)   The expressed or implied repeal or amendment by this chapter of any
ordinance or part of any ordinance does not affect any rights or liabilities
accrued, penalties incurred or proceedings begun prior to the effective date of
this chapter. Those rights, liabilities, and proceedings are continued, and
penalties shall be imposed and enforced under the repealed or amended ordinance
as if this chapter had not been adopted.
   (B)   Should any provision (section, paragraph, sentence clause, or any
other portion) of this chapter be declared by a court of competent jurisdiction
to be invalid for any reason, the remaining provision or provisions shall not
be affected, if and only if such remaining provisions can, without the invalid
provision or provisions, be given the effect intended by the City Council in
adopting this chapter. To this end the provisions of this chapter are
severable.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.191 EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This chapter shall be in effect from and after its passage by the City
Council and compliance with IC 22-13-2-5.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
§ 94.999 PENALTY.
   Penalties hereby imposed and identified pursuant to the City of Beech Grove
Fire Prevention and Protection Code identified in this chapter, as set out
under the Indiana Code for violations found, are hereby adopted and approved
upon the approval of the State of Indiana Fire Prevention and Building Safety
Commission and upon passage of this chapter by the City Council.
(Ord. 1-2003, passed 5-5-03)
