GARBAGE COLLECTION
§ 96.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   GARBAGE. Food stuffs and food products, usable or unusable, including any
matter or substance in connection therewith, placed and deposited in a
container required by the city for the purpose of collection of the same as
garbage.
('67 Code, § 94.01)
   TRASH AND REFUSE. Any ashes, papers, cans, bottles, discarded household
articles or materials, grass, earthenware, and all other described substances
discarded by a householder or apartment dweller which may be deposited in
refuse cans or other suitable containers meeting the requirements of the Board
of Public Works and Safety of the city, not to exceed 32 gallon capacity.
However, "TRASH AND REFUSE" shall not include large household appliances or
machines such as refrigerators, stoves, furnaces, water heaters, or building or
construction materials, including but not limited to earth, sand, cinders,
rock, concrete (broken or otherwise) roofing, lumber, gravel, sod, and similar
materials.
(Ord. 14-1976, passed 10-18-76)
§ 96.02 COLLECTION OF GARBAGE.
   (A)   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall provide the necessary
personnel and equipment for the collection of all garbage and refuse within the
city authorized to be collected by this chapter.
   (B)   The Board of Public Works and Safety shall provide for regular
collection service for garbage, trash, and refuse defined in §
96.01, and may promulgate rules and regulations governing such routes and
services. Provided, however, that in no event shall the city pick up trash,
garbage, or refuse unless it is placed at the curb or alley line of a street or
alley abutting the premises from which a collection is to be made on the day
and prior to the time for collection as determined by the Board of Public Works
and Safety, and provided further that such trash, garbage, or refuse shall be
placed in suitable containers or neatly bundled and tied as determined by the
Board.
   (C)   Board of Public Works and Safety may provide for collection of other
refuse, trash, and junk at times and in a manner convenient to the city. The
Board may, but need not, require a fee for the collection of all trash, junk,
and refuse except that defined in §
96.01. Such fee shall take into consideration the time, labor, and equipment
necessary to accomplish any such collection but in no event shall any
collection or pick up be made except at the curb line, alley line, or inner
edge of the roadway of the street or alley abutting the premises from which
such trash, junk, or refuse is to be collected. All fees and charges shall be
uniform and applied generally throughout the city.
(Ord. 14-1976, passed 10-18-76)
Cross-reference:
   Keeping garbage on premises, see §
98.01
   Rates for collection of heavy items, see §
96.05
§ 96.03 NOTICE OF RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   All regulations, rules, and fee schedules shall be communicated to all
property owners of the city by either delivery of the same to each premises
from which collection is to be made or by notice published at least one time in
a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least ten days prior to
implementation. In addition, as much publicity and notice as is possible shall
be given by means of the various media available.
(Ord. 14-1976, passed 10-18-76)
§ 96.04 REGULATIONS FOR TRASH COLLECTION.
   (A)   All trash containers shall be placed at the curb line or alley line
within 24 hours of pick up. Department of Public Works employees shall not
access private property to collect trash. Trash containers shall be removed
from the curb line and the public right-of-way within 24 hours of being
emptied. Trash containers shall not be required to be moved from the alley
line.
   (B)   Blue trash containers (totes) marked “The City of Beech Grove” are the
preferred containers. It is recommended that different containers not be used
to prevent lifting injuries to Department of Public Works employees.
   (C)   All refuse shall be placed in the approved blue container (Tote)
labeled “City of Beech Grove”. All other containers will not be picked up.
Refuse not placed in the approved blue container (Tote) labeled “City of Beech
Grove” will not be picked up. Wood and tree shrubbery is not construed as trash
and will be picked up via a chipper machine or brush truck when these vehicles
become available.
   (D)   Any fee derived for the collection of normal trash shall be produced
monthly on the Beech Grove sewage works bill.
   (E)   Any single or double family dwelling (unit) that utilizes more than
two trash containers shall be billed $5 per each trash container emptied (after
the second one) on each sewage works billing period.
(Res. passed 11-1-76; Am. Ord. 23, 2012, passed 8-6-12; Am. Ord. 5, 2016,
passed 4-4-16) Penalty, see §
96.99
§ 96.05 COLLECTION OF HEAVY APPLIANCES AND ITEMS.
   The following items will not be picked up by employees of the Department of
Public Works or any authorized agent on behalf of the City of Beech Grove:
   (A)   Stoves;
   (B)   Refrigerators;
   (C)   Freezers;
   (D)   Microwave ovens;
   (E)   Washers;
   (F)   Dryers;
   (G)   Dishwashers;
   (H)   Water heaters;
   (I)   Furnaces;
   (J)   Outdoor grills;
   (K)   Air conditioning units;
   (L)   Dehumidifiers;
   (M)   Any other appliance deemed hazardous or dangerous by the Director of
the Department.
(Ord. 18, 2014, passed 12-1-14)
§ 96.06 FREON AND OTHER GASES AND LIQUIDS.
   (A)   Notwithstanding §
96.04 or any other provision, employees of the Department of Public Works shall
not handle any object, container, or appliance that could or does contain a
combustible liquid, combustible gas, flammable gas or flammable liquid.
   (B)   Citizens who place these items out for disposal shall be informed that
a licensed private technician or company must dispose of these items. The city
cannot dispose of these items for them.
(Ord. 18, 2014, passed 12-1-14)
§ 96.07 UNIFORM SOLID WASTE FEE.
   (A)   Notwithstanding any other provision of the Code, there is hereby
established a monthly uniform solid waste fee to cover all costs to the city of
collecting, treating, and disposing of garbage, trash, and refuse, as defined
in §
96.01, in a sanitary manner, including the cost of equipment and wages
therefore, as allowed and provided by IC 36-9-23-25(d)(8).
   (B)   Notwithstanding any other provision of the Code, all costs relating to
collecting, treating and disposing of garbage in a sanitary manner, as provided
in this chapter, shall be included in and accounted for as a cost of the city’s
sewage works as provided in this chapter, shall be included in and accounted
for as a cost of the city’s sewage works as provided for and allowed by IC 36-
9-23-25(d)(8).
   (C)   Effective with the sewer user billing in August of 2004, the uniform
solid waste fee provided for herein shall be billed to the users set forth in §
50.47(B) in addition to the sewer rates and billings established in
Chapter 50. Fees collected shall be considered revenues of the sewage works.
(Ord. 4A-2004, passed 8-17-04)
§ 96.08 SOLID WASTE INCLUDED IN SEWAGE WORKS; AUTHORITY OF BOARD OF SANITATION.
   As provided in IC 36-9-30-7(b), the control, administration and supervision
of all functions, facilities, personnel and equipment utilized in the
collection, treatment and disposal of solid waste in the city, including all
functions and responsibilities provided for in this chapter, shall be
transferred from the Board of Public Works and Safety to the Board of
Sanitation, and shall be included in and accounted for as a cost of the city’s
sewage works. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, all
references in this chapter to "Board" or "Board of Public Works and Safety"
shall hereafter refer to the Board of Sanitation.
(Ord. 4A-2004, passed 8-17-04)
§ 96.09 TRASH CONTAINER (TOTE) PROGRAM.
   (A)   Each single and double family dwelling was issued one trash container
(tote). Should a request for a trash container (tote) be asked for after
General Ordinance No. 15, 2012 goes into effect, the City of Beech Grove shall
pass on the cost of the trash container (tote) to the person(s) residing on the
property. Such fee shall not exceed the cost to the city of a 96-, 64-, or 48-
gallon trash container (tote) at the time the request was made.
   (B)   The city shall only charge the cost (to the city) of the respective
trash container (tote).
   (C)   The city shall not charge a delivery fee or a set up fee when
delivering new trash containers (tote) to a single or double family dwelling.
   (D)   The trash container (tote) becomes part of the residential property
and should not be taken when moving from the listed property. Should a resident
move and take the trash container (tote) with them, and upon discovery by the
Department of Public Works, the city has the right to bill the respective
property owner listed for the address for the cost of the removed trash
container (tote). Such costs shall not exceed the cost to the city of a 96-,
64-, or 48-gallon trash container (tote) at the time the request was made.
   (E)   In the event a trash container is damaged, the Director of Public
Works shall inspect the trash container (tote) and make a determination on the
replacement process. Should the damage be a result of actions not caused by the
respective resident or the property owner, then all costs associated with the
replacement of the trash container (tote) shall be waived. Included in this is
if the trash container (tote) becomes damaged by employees of the City of Beech
Grove while disposing of trash.
   (F)   There shall be no charge to replace misplaced or broken lids pursuant
to the 96- gallon, 64-gallon, and 48-gallon trash container (tote).
   (G)   The Director of Public Works shall be responsible to maintain an
adequate inventory of trash containers (totes) and replacement lids for
residential usage.
   (H)   Any and all billing pursuant to the trash container (tote) program
shall be through the monthly sewage works bill.
   (I)   Should a trash container (tote) that clearly states “The City of Beech
Grove” be seen outside of the City of Beech Grove, such notification shall be
made to the Director of the Department of Public Works for retrieval of the
trash container (tote).
   (J)   (1)   The Director of the Department of Public Works shall conduct a
suitable inventory of the trash container (tote) program throughout the City of
Beech Grove as part of the assets in inventory program. Such identification
numbers shall be forwarded to the sanitation clerk for proper computer filing.
      (2)   A representative of the City of Beech Grove who participates in
conducting an inventory of the trash container (tote) program shall not access
private property for the purpose of conducting an inventory. Such inventory
must take place when the respective trash container (tote) is in a public place
and is ready to be serviced.
(Ord. 15, 2012, passed 6-4-12)
§ 96.10 HANDLING OF WASTE RESTRICTED.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for a person to take waste from a dumpster
container or bag when the container has been placed on public city owned
property without a permit other than the property owner and the Beech Grover
Department of Sanitation.
   (B)   Waste may only be picked up from dawn until dusk.
   (C)   Permits obtained through City Hall must include a government issued
identification number and are good for a period of one year and cost of $5.
(Ord. 3, 2013, passed 4-1-13)
REFUSE DISPOSAL
§ 96.15 BURNING TRASH AND LEAVES ON STREETS.
   No person shall burn any leaves or trash on any improved street within the
corporate limits of the city.
('67 Code, § 94.05) Penalty, see §
96.99
Cross-reference:
   Fire prevention, see
Ch. 94
RATES
§ 96.25 CHARGES FOR HEAVY TRASH PICK UP, BRUSH REMOVAL, MATTRESS AND BOX
SPRINGS PICK UP.
   Fees for the collection of heavy trash, brush and the pick up of mattresses
and box springs are hereby affixed and established by the Common Council
according to the following guidelines:
   (A)   Heavy trash.
      (1)   Minimum charge is $25. The Director of the Department of Public
Works has the authority to increase the charge based on what has been placed
out for pick up. The amount of time to pick up, quantity of trash, and the
weight of the trash placed out for disposal are factors in determining the
appropriate charge.
      (2)   Maximum charge is $500. The Director of the Department of Public
Works shall not exceed this amount for the charge to remove heavy trash.
      (3)   The resident or property owner shall agree to the pre-set amount
prior to any heavy trash being removed.
      (4)   Upon agreement of the set price, the heavy trash will be removed
and the service charge will be placed on the next available Beech Grove Sewage
Works’ bill.
      (5)   The date and time of heavy trash pick up will be at the convenience
of the Department of Public Works.
      (6)   The Director of the Department of Public Works has the authority to
refuse to pick up heavy trash based on health, environmental or other
conditions presented.
   (B)   Brush.
      (1)   Minimum charge is $25. The Director of the Department of Public
Works has the authority to increase that charge based on the amount of brush
placed out for disposal. The amount of time to either chip or remove, including
using a pay loader, all factors in on the charge.
      (2)   Maximum charge is $800. The Director of the Department of Public
Works shall not exceed this amount for the charge to remove brush.
      (3)   The resident or property owner shall agree to the pre-set amount
prior to any brush being removed.
      (4)   Upon agreement the brush will be removed and the agreed set price
agreed to will be placed on the next available Beech Grove Sewage Works’ bill.
      (5)   The date and time for brush removal will be at the convenience of
the Department of Public Works.
      (6)   The Director of the Department of Public Works has the discretion
to waive any and all fees for the removal of brush due to storms, accidents, or
any other acts of nature.
      (7)   The Director of the Department of Public Works has the discretion
to not to pick up brush, based on the conditions presented at the time of
inspection.
   (C)   Mattresses and box springs.
      (1)   Minimum charge is $20 per box spring and mattress. The Director of
the Department of Public Works has the authority to set the schedule and times
when mattresses and box springs will be picked up.
      (2)   The Director of the Department of Public Works shall schedule and
provide an outside trash service the addresses for the mattresses and box
springs that have been placed for trash pick up. Employees of the Department of
Public Works shall not handle any mattresses or box springs.
      (3)   The Director of the Department of Public Works shall provide
billing information to the Sewage Works Clerk so charges for mattresses and box
springs that have been discarded can be placed on the earliest available Beech
Grove Sewage Works bill for residences who have utilized the pick up of their
mattresses and box springs.
(Ord. 23, 2014, passed 12-1-14; Am. Ord. 27, 2016, 1-3-17)
COMMERCIAL TRASH PICK-UP PROGRAM
§ 96.35 VOLUNTARY PARTICIPATION.
   Local businesses have the option as to whether they desire to participate in
the commercial trash pick-up program or not.
(Ord. 16, 2012, passed 6-4-12)
§ 96.36 TYPES OF TRASH CONTAINERS AUTHORIZED FOR USE.
   (A)   The only type of approved trash container (tote) that is authorized
for usage is the 96-gallon trash container (tote) with the “City of Beech
Grove” identified on the trash container (tote) itself.
   (B)   No other trash container will be authorized for usage including
dumpsters.
(Ord 16, 2012, passed 6-4-12)
§ 96.37 COST TO PARTICIPATE IN COMMERCIAL TRASH PICK-UP SERVICE.
   (A)   The cost per month for each trash container (tote) shall be as
follows:
 
Effective February 24, 2020 $20
Effective January 1, 2021   $21
Effective January 1, 2022   $21
Effective January 1, 2023   $22
 
   (B)   There shall not be a fee for a trash container (tote) delivered and
set up to the business.
   (C)   Any and all fees associated with the commercial trash pick-up service
shall be included on the monthly Beech Grove sewage works bill.
(Ord. 16, 2012, passed 6-4-12; Am. Ord. 1, 2020, passed 2-18-20)
§ 96.38 SCHEDULE FOR COMMERCIAL TRASH PICK- UP SERVICE.
   (A)   The program shall be under the Direction of the Department of Public
Works Director, and such Director shall establish a weekly pick-up schedule.
   (B)   The Department of Public Works shall pick up each trash container
(tote) twice weekly unless otherwise directed by the Director of the Department
of Public Works.
   (C)   The city and/or the respective business involved have/has the right to
discontinue such commercial trash pick-up service by giving a 30-day written
notice to the City of Beech Grove and/or the respective business.
   (D)   Unless a business signs up for the commercial trash pick-up service,
the city shall discontinue such service to current users unless they agree to
the terms of this subchapter. The only exception would the City of Beech Grove
School System and the Beech Grove Public Library which are other governmental
units within the City of Beech Grove.
(Ord. 16, 2012, passed 6-4-12)
§ 96.39 PROCEDURE TO PICK UP COMMERCIAL TRASH.
   (A)   Trash containers (totes) shall be brought to the alley line or at the
back of the building for service. Trash containers (totes) will not be picked
up in front of a business.
   (B)   Employees of the Department of Public Works shall not proceed on
private property for the purpose of gathering trash containers (totes) for
service.
   (C)   The approved trash containers (totes) will be the only container
serviced. Trash found lying beside the trash container (tote) will not be
picked up.
   (D)   Trash containers (totes) shall not be placed in the storefront of a
building.
   (E)   Medical waste and/or hazardous, combustible, or flammable liquids or
solids will not be picked up.
(Ord. 16, 2012, passed 6-4-12)
RECYCLING PROGRAM
§ 96.50 RECYCLING.
   The City of Beech Grove desires to provide a citywide recycling program for
the following groups of people, municipal departments, and public events:
   (A)   Single and double family dwellings;
   (B)   Department of Parks and Recreation;
   (C)   Municipal properties;
   (D)   Special events approved by the Board of Public Works and Safety.
(Ord. 1, 2015, passed 3-2-15)
§ 96.51 SUPERVISION.
   The recycling program shall be under the direction of the Director of the
Department of Public Works and shall conform to the following guidelines:
   (A)   Employees of the Department of Public Works shall not have any
responsibility in picking up recyclable materials or containers.
   (B)   The city shall not be responsible for the inventory, distribution,
maintenance of any container, equipment or vehicle used to collect recyclables.
   (C)   The Director of the Department of Public Works shall set up the routes
for recycling pick up.
(Ord. 1, 2015, passed 3-2-15)
§ 96.52 COLLECTION.
   (A)   Containers shall not be set out for collection on the curb line or
alley line unless it is within a 24-hour pick up.
   (B)   Containers shall be removed from the curb line or alley line within 24
hours of pick up.
   (C)   Recyclables will not be picked up unless they are in the approved
containers.
   (D)   Damage to or removal of containers provided for recycling shall be
mitigated between the residents and the contractor providing the recycling
service.
   (E)   Recycling pick up shall not occur on a recognized City of Beech Grove
holiday.
   (F)   Recycling pick up shall not occur on a Saturday or Sunday.
   (G)   Recycling pick up operations shall not start before 7:00 a.m. or
proceed after 4:00 p.m. on any given day.
   (H)   The recycling company shall provide collection service on a two-week
route basis as determined by the Director of the Department of Public Works
beginning on July 1, 2015.
   (I)   The recycling pick up schedule can be modified at the discretion of
the Director of the Department of Public Works.
   (J)   Municipal properties and city park pick ups will be scheduled on a
two-week basis but can be adjusted by the Director of the Department of Public
Works.
   (K)   Collection for special events will be under the direction of the
Director of the Department of Public Works.
(Ord. 1, 2015, passed 3-2-15)
§ 96.53 CONTAINER.
   (A)   The recycling company shall provide containers for recycling.
   (B)   The container shall have a yellow lid, two wheels and contain 96-
gallon storage capacity.
   (C)   The recycling company shall deliver one container to each single
family dwelling and one container to each side of a double dwelling.
   (D)   The recycling company shall deliver the appropriate containers to each
municipal department and within the Department of Parks and Recreation.
   (E)   The recycling company under the direction of the Director of the
Department of Public Works shall deliver an adequate amount of recyclable
containers to each special event that has been approved by the City of Beech
Grove.
   (F)   Repairs, replacement and inventory shall be the sole responsibility of
the recycling company.
   (G)   The recycling company shall provide instructions along with the
delivery of the container on what is the best practice to handle the container.
(Ord. 1, 2015, passed 3-2-15)
§ 96.54 RECYCLABLE MATERIALS.
   As a minimum the following items shall be considered as recyclable and
should be placed in the approved container:
   (A)   Newsprint;
   (B)   Computer paper;
   (C)   Writing paper;
   (D)   Copy paper;
   (E)   Envelopes;
   (F)   Junk mail;
   (G)   Magazines;
   (H)   Newspapers;
   (I)   Beverage cans;
   (J)   Food cans;
   (K)   #1 through #7 plastics;
   (L)   Corrugated cardboard;
   (M)   Cardboard;
   (N)   Paper board;
   (O)   Clear bottles;
   (P)   Brown bottles;
   (Q)   Green bottles;
   (R)   Food jars;
   (S)   Steel;
   (T)   Aluminum;
   (U)   Bi-metal beverage cans;
   (V)   Any other commodity as prescribed by the Director of the Department of
Public Works.
(Ord. 1, 2015, passed 3-2-15)
§ 96.55 REPORTING; BILLING.
   (A)   The recycling company shall report quarterly to the Board of
Sanitation the amounts collected and any problems associated with the recycling
program.
   (B)   The recycling company shall bill the City of Beech Grove, Beech Grove
Sewage Works monthly for providing recycling services.
   (C)   Property owners of single and double family dwellings and special
event participants shall not pay a fee for recycling. Municipal properties
shall be charged for monthly recycling services.
(Ord. 1, 2015, passed 3-2-15)
§ 96.56 COLLECTION EQUIPMENT.
   (A)   The recycling contractor shall provide an adequate number of vehicles
for regular collection of recyclables. Vehicles must be in good repair,
appearance and in a sanitary condition at all times.
   (B)   The recycling contractor shall provide adequate containment of all
collectables by tying or enclosing collectables to prevent leaking, spilling,
and blowing disposables that derive from the collection of recycled materials.
(Ord. 1, 2015, passed 3-2-15)
§ 96.57 COMPLAINTS; PUBLIC EDUCATION.
   (A)   Complaints from residential households shall be made directly to the
City of Beech Grove and shall be given prompt and courteous attention. In the
case of alleged missed schedule collections, the city shall investigate and if
such allegations are verified, shall arrange for the collection of the recycled
materials within 24 hours of the compliant being received.
   (B)   The contractor at their cost shall provide residents with information
and educational materials concerning recycling. Such materials shall be
distributed at least 30 days before the program starts. Every six months
thereafter, and until the agreement ends the contractor shall provide at their
cost a public service announcement via United States mail to the residents of
Beech Grove concerning recycling and cleaning up our city. The Director of the
Department of Public Works shall approve all materials prior to distribution.
(Ord. 1, 2015, passed 3-2-15)
§ 96.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates any section of this chapter for which another penalty
is not already otherwise provided, shall be subject to the penalty as set forth
in §
10.99.
   (B)   A violation of §
96.10 shall be subject to a fine of not less than $50.
   (C)   Whoever violates §
96.15 shall be fined not less than $10 nor more than $1,000.
('67 Code, § 94.99) (Am. Ord. 3, 2013, passed 4-1-13)
CHAPTER 97: RESERVED
CHAPTER 98: PUBLIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL NUISANCES
Section
   
98.01   Definitions
   
98.02   Public nuisances prohibited
   
98.03   Property owner to maintain premises free of nuisances
   
98.04   Public nuisances
   
98.05   Notice to abate
   
98.06   Citation for failure to abate nuisance
   
98.07   Abatement of nuisance by city
   
98.08   Procedure for city’s collection of abatement costs
   
98.09   Right to contest city’s bill for costs
 
   
98.98   Violations
   
98.99   Penalty
§ 98.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   “PROPERTY.” A lot or parcel of real estate including, in addition to those
within their respective boundaries, all of the buildings, structures,
dwellings, or grounds lying between the property line and the improved portion
of adjacent streets or alleys, and utility easements.
   “PROPERTY OWNER.” All persons, entities or organizations who are responsible
for the payment of taxes on the real estate. There is a rebuttable presumption
that the records of the city’s Sewage Works Billing Department reflect the
identity of the property owner.
   “PUBLIC NUISANCE.” The doing of an unlawful act, or the omitting to perform
a duty, or the suffering or permitting of any condition or thing to be or
exist, which act, omission, condition or thing either:
      (1)   Injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of
others; or
      (2)   Offends decency; or
      (3)   Is offensive to the senses; or
      (4)   Unlawfully interferes with, obstructs or tends to obstruct or
renders dangerous for passage any public or private street, highway, sidewalk,
stream, ditch or drainage; or
      (5)   In any way renders other persons insecure in life or the use of
property; or
      (6)   Essentially interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life and
property or tends to depreciate the value of the property of others.
(Ord. 4, 2014, passed 6-2-14; Ord. 4, 2024, passed 9-3-24)
§ 98.02 PUBLIC NUISANCE PROHIBITED.
   No person shall erect, contrive, cause, continue, maintain, or permit to
exist any public nuisance as defined in § 98.01.
(Ord. 4, 2014, passed 6-2-14; Am. Ord. 4, 2024, passed 9-3-24) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.03 PUBLIC NUISANCES PROHIBITED.
   It is unlawful for any property owner, occupant, or other person to allow a
public nuisance to exist. Nothing in this chapter should be construed to
encourage or authorize the discrimination by lessors against any person based
upon race, creed, religion, sex, age, sexual orientation, gender, veteran
status or national origin.
(Ord. 4, 2014, passed 6-2-14)
§ 98.04 PUBLIC NUISANCES.
   (A)   It is the purpose of this chapter to protect the public safety,
health, and welfare and enhance the environment of the citizens of the city by
making it unlawful to allow a person to maintain a public nuisance. This
chapter shall be enforced or administered by the Department of Compliance and/
or the Police Department where appropriate.
   (B)   Conditions constituting a public nuisance. It shall be unlawful for
any property owner, occupant, manager or person having control of any property
to permit or cause a public nuisance to develop, including, but not limited to
the following:
      (1)   Any growth of weeds, grass or other vegetation which is either:
         (a)   Neglected, disregarded or not adequately managed or controlled,
cut, mowed or removed;
         (b)   Has attained a height of nine inches or more; or
         (c)   Is actually or imminently detrimental to the public health,
safety or welfare;
      (2)   Boxes, appliances, furniture, household items, tires, tools,
fixtures, and construction debris;
      (3)   Any junk automobiles, broken concrete, scrap metal or automobile
parts;
      (4)   Fallen trees, stumps, or dead trees;
      (5)   Wood stacked or lying on the ground;
      (6)   Accumulation of rubbish, trash, garbage, refuse, junk and other
abandoned materials;
      (7)   Emission of a significant amount of odor, dust, smoke, soot,
noxious fumes, or other matter into the atmosphere which renders ordinary use
and enjoyment of property in the vicinity uncomfortable or impossible;
      (8)   Any dead animal;
      (9)   The erection of a dam or any other obstruction by a private party
which prevents the flow of water and causes it to collect or pool upon any
private property;
      (10)   Any wastewater, filth, garbage, trash, rubbish, animal waste, or
human excrement which is deposited, allowed or caused to be upon any property;
      (11)   Any trees, shrubbery, weeds, snow, fences, or other materials that
obstruct public ways or cause a visual barrier for vehicular traffic;
      (12)   Any building or other structure which is in such disrepair or a
dilapidated condition that it is unfit for human habitation, kept in such an
unsanitary condition that is a menace to the health of people residing in the
vicinity thereof, or presents a more than ordinarily dangerous fire hazard in
the vicinity where it is located;
      (13)   Structure defaced with paint or wording;
      (14)   Any unnecessary or unauthorized noises and annoying vibrations;
      (15)   Any accumulation of stagnant water permitted or maintained on any
lot or piece of ground;
      (16)   No person shall kindle or maintain any bonfire or burn leaves,
rubbish or dispose of any refuse by open burning, or such fire, or authorizes
any such fire to be kindled or maintained on or in any street, alley, road,
land or public grounds.
         (a)   No person shall kindle or maintain any bonfire, burn leaves,
trash or rubbish on any private land or dispose of unwanted goods by open
burning on private land. (See division (B)(16)(b) for exclusions.)
         (b)   Small fires for the purpose of wiener roast, comfort fires, hog
roast and other specialty cooking with open flame is permitted, provided the
open fire is contained in an approved container with access to a lid, or is in
the ground six inches in depth, surrounded by cement blocks or bricks extending
at least six inches in height. The fire pit may not exceed an internal diameter
of 48 inches.
         (c)   Public safety agencies upon notification may have cause to
conduct an inspection and if conditions are unsafe may ask for you to
extinguish the fire.
         (d)   The fire pit must be 15 feet away from any residential
structures including houses, garages and barns. It must also be 15 feet away
from overhead utility fines. This is determined by measuring the point on the
ground in which the utility crossed and measuring to the fire pit.
         (e)   Operable garden hose and/or a five-gallon bucket of water must
be readily available to extinguish the fire if necessary.
         (f)   Person over the age of 18 must be present at the residence when
a bonfire is lit;
      (17)   The unauthorized obstruction of any public street, road or
sidewalk;
      (18)   Open excavations, uncovered or improperly covered holes, whether
lined or unlined, and dirt piles on any open or unfenced real property,
including open foundations;
      (19)   Vegetation growing in a gutter of a structure or building;
      (20)   Any condition which provides harborage for rats, mice, snakes and
other vermin;
      (21)   Any building, structure or other place or location where any
activity which is in violation of any city ordinance, or state or federal law
is conducted, performed or maintained;
      (22)   A condition which caused property to become a health and safety
hazard;
      (23)   Those offenses which are known in common law and state statutes as
public nuisances; and
      (24)   Any other condition that prevents one from the use and enjoyment
of his or her property.
(Ord. 4, 2014, passed 6-2-14; Am. Ord. 12, 2015, passed 7-6-15; Am. Ord. 6,
2017, passed 8-7-17; Am. Ord. 4, 2024, passed 9-3-24)
§ 98.05 NOTICE TO ABATE.
   (A)   Whenever a public nuisance is found to exist, the city will provide
written notice to the property owner.
   (B)   The notice shall provide the property owner ten calendar days from the
date of the notice to bring the property into compliance as set forth in the
notice.
   (C)   The notice shall provide:
      (1)   A statement of the nature and location of the alleged public
nuisance;
      (2)   A statement of acts deemed necessary to correct the condition;
      (3)   A date not sooner than ten calendar days from the date of the
notice when the property owner must comply with the issues addressed in the
notice; and
      (4)   A statement that if the alleged public nuisance is not abated as
directed, the city may abate the public nuisance and assess the cost thereof
against the property owner, occupant, or person having a beneficial interest in
the property, and that such cost will constitute a lien against the property.
   (D)   All notices as herein required shall be sent by United States mail,
first class postage prepaid, to the property owner as reflected in the records
of the city’s Sewage Works Billing Department. If there is no active Sewage
Works Billing Department account, then notice shall be sent to any party having
property ownership of the property as on record with the Marion County
Assessor’s Office and/or the Marion County Recorder’s Office. Absent a return
to sender notice from the Postal Service, it is presumed that the property
owner received the notice or citation.
(Ord. 4, 2014, passed 6-2-14; Am. Ord. 12, 2015, passed 7-6-15; Am. Ord. 4,
2024, passed 9-3-24)
§ 98.06 CITATION FOR FAILURE TO ABATE NUISANCE.
   (A)   Whenever the Department of Compliance, after the expiration of ten
calendar days of the date of the notice, determines that the property owner has
failed to abate the nuisance, the Department of Compliance shall issue a
citation to the property owner.
   (B)   Upon the expiration of ten calendar days of the date of the first
citation, if the Department of Compliance determines that the property is still
out of compliance, a second citation shall be issued to the property owner.
   (C)   Ten calendar days after the date of the second citation, if the
Department of Compliance determines that the property is still out of
compliance, a third citation shall be issued to the property owner.
   (D)   For purposes of issuing additional citations for the same violation,
each subsequent day shall be considered a separate chargeable offense, and
additional
citations shall be issued to the property owner absent the ten calendar day
period.
   (E)   All citations are served on the property owner shall be done so
consistent with §
98.05 (D).
   (F)   A one-year statute of limitations shall apply to the issuance of any
subsequent citations.
(Ord. 4, 2024, passed 9-3-24) Penalty, see §
98.99
§ 98.07 ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE BY CITY.
   (A)   Upon failure of the property owner to comply with the notice to abate,
in addition to the issuance of additional citations under this chapter, the
Department of Compliance may, at the discretion of the Mayor, take measures to
abate the nuisance by any reasonable means. In such instance, the Department of
Compliance shall provide notice to the property owner, in writing, at least 72
hours in advance of entering the real estate, of its intent to enter and abate.
Such notice may be left at the property upon which the condition exists, mailed
to the property owner by United States mail, first class postage prepaid, or
hand delivered to the property owner.
   (B)   In the event the city takes measures to abate a nuisance, the property
owner shall be charged for the abatement costs.
(Ord. 4, 2014, passed 6-2-14; Am. Ord. 4, 2024, passed 9-3-24)
§ 98.08 PROCEDURE FOR CITY’S COLLECTION OF ABATEMENT COSTS.
   (A)   The Department of Compliance shall make and issue to the property
owner a bill for all costs incurred by the city in abatement of the public
nuisance. The costs billed to the property owner under this section shall
include all actual costs incurred by the city, including without limitation to,
the cost of a private contractor, labor costs for utilizing the services of
city employees, equipment and supply costs, and the cost of all postage. The
property owner shall pay the amount of the bill to the Clerk-Treasurer's office
within 30 calendar days of the date of the bill.
   (B)   If the 30-day period in division (A) has expired, and the bill is not
paid in full, then the bill for all such costs which the property owner has
failed to pay shall be considered delinquent.
   (C)   Whenever the Department of Compliance deems it necessary, it shall
prepare a list of delinquent fees, penalties, and costs that are enforceable
under §
98.07 , including:
      (1)   The name or names of the property owners of each lot or parcel of
real property on which fees, penalties and costs are delinquent;
      (2)   Description of the premises, as shown on the records of the Sewage
Works Billing Department;
      (3)   Amount of the delinquent fees, penalties and costs due under this
chapter; or all instrument for each lot or parcel of real property on which the
fees are delinquent.
   (D)   Collection of abatement costs
Upon being provided the information set forth in division (C), the Clerk-
Treasurer may engage in the following:
      (1)   Assess the abatement costs on the property owner’s monthly bill
issued by the Sewage Works Billing Department;
      (2)   Record a copy of each list or each instrument with the County
Recorder in accordance with IC 36-l-6-2(e); or
      (3)   Provide a copy of the recorded list or instrument to the County
Auditor to be placed on the tax duplicate for that property, with the result
that the amount so certified shall be collected as delinquent taxes are
collected in accordance with IC 36-l-6-2(f).
(Ord. 4, 2014, passed 6-2-14; Am. Ord. 12, 2015, passed 7-6-15; Am. Ord. 4,
2024, passed 9-3-24)
§ 98.09 RIGHT TO CONTEST CITY’S BILL FOR COSTS.
   (A)   The property owner may object to a bill for the city’s abatement costs
by filing a written objection to the Department of Compliance within 30
calendar days of the date of the bill. Failure to file a timely written
objection results in a waiver of the property owner’s right to object, and
payment of the bill is due immediately.
   (B)   The property owner’s written objection may be hand delivered or mailed
to the Department of Compliance located at City Hall or sent via electronic
mail at compliance@beechgrove.com all within 30 calendar days of the date of
the citation.
   (C)   If the Department of Compliance receives a timely written objection
from the property owner, the Board of Public Works and Safety shall set a
hearing and allow the property owner an opportunity to be heard. The Board of
Public Works and Safety may affirm the city’s costs, deny them, or issue a
finding modifying the bill. The decision made by the Board of Public Works and
Safety is final.
   (D)   In the event of an adverse finding, the bill shall be paid by the
property owner no later than 14 calendar days after the Board of Public Works
and Safety’s decision. If the property owner does not timely pay the bill, the
city shall follow the procedures in §
98.08 .
(Ord. 4, 2014, passed 6-2-14; Am. Ord. 4, 2024, passed 9-4-2024)
§ 98.98 VIOLATIONS.
   Upon issuance of a citation to a property owner, the citation shall be
placed in the city’s Ordinance Violations Bureau, where it will remain for a
period of 60 calendar days. Within that 60-calendar day period, the property
owner may pay the citation for the amount issued. However, if the 60-calendar
day period expires, and the property owner has not paid the citation, the
citation shall be docketed into the City Court, where it will be assigned a
cause number, assessed statutory court costs, and set for trial.
(Ord. 4, 2014, passed 6-2-14; Am. Ord. 4, 2024, passed 9-3-24)
§ 98.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Unless, otherwise provided, the property owner shall be fined $100 for
a first offense, $250 for a second offense, and $500 for the third and any
subsequent offenses.
   (B)   Each day after the expiration date of the time limit ordered for
abatement stated in the notice to abate shall constitute a distinct and
separate offense.
   (C)   The court may award the city reimbursement of its attorney fees and
costs at the request of the City Attorney.
(Ord. 4, 2014, passed 6-2-14; Am. Ord. 4, 2024, passed 9-3-24)
